results.title: A Conversation with B.F. Skinner (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Peter Jordan, CRM Educational Films and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: In his book Beyond Freedom and Dignity, Dr. B. F. Skinner rejects the general belief that within each individual there is an “inner man” immune to environmental shaping. In discussion with Elizabeth Hall of Psychology Today magazine, he illuminates the origins of behaviorism and some of its basic principles and argues the need for a culture designed by behaviorists. Within this context, he explores the notion of control, its use and potential misuse, punishment and freedom.

results.title: A Continuing responsibility
results.creator_credit: Bonnie Sherr Klein, Barrie Howells, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Produced as part of the Challenge for Change Program, this series examines Saul Alinsky’s method of organising communities into effective action units based on participation democracy. As demonstrated in the Woodland Organisation in Chicago, Alinsky’s technique creates ongoing organisations firmly rooted in the community.

results.title: A Continent on guard
results.creator_credit: Bob Walker, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Presents a dramatic, simulated investigation into a suspected outbreak of foot and mouth disease in Australia, and points out what measures would be taken to eradicate the disease. Note: A complementary production to ‘The constant threat’

results.title: A Connecticut yankee in King Arthur's court
results.brief_description: In this imaginative story by Mark Twain, a modern man suddenly finds himself in the kingdom of King Arthur when he receives a blow to the head. Twain very cleverly compares the two eras customs and attitudes through this entertaining fantasy as the modern Yankee has fun introducing modern innovations to Arthur’s kingdom. No other production details available.

results.title: A Conceptual approach to teaching
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Malcolm Smith, Education Dept of South Australia and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The problems presented by what is popularly called “the information explosion” are no more keenly felt than by teachers and students. This film appraises current teaching methodology and provides a basis for discussion to provoke new thoughts and ideas on teaching techniques. Designed as an in-service aid for re-assessing and re-evaluating teaching programs and methodologies and provide a starting point for curriculum development.

results.title: A Computer glossary, or, coming to terms with the data processing machine
results.creator_credit: Ray Eames, Charles Eames, Richard Spies, Bill Lightfield and IBM
results.brief_description: Beginning with a journey along a computer data path, this films uses a variety of visual techniques to illustrate terms such as software, program, flow, subroutine, mnemonic, language, boolean logic, nanosecond, simulation, pattern recognition and algorithm. Emphasises the challenge of computer programming that emerges from its precisely defined procedures. Music by Elmer Bernstein.
results.title_for_label: A Computer glossary, or, coming to terms with the data processing machine

results.title: A Composition in steel by Todd Pendleton with Jack Pendleton
results.creator_credit: James Klebau and James Klebau Productions
results.brief_description: The film shows the two Pendleton brothers, Todd and Jack, making a steel sculpture starting from the initial design in chalk on a metal base, then the selection, cutting and the beating of the scrap metal to shape. Finally they weld the shapes together modifying the design as they go.

results.title: A Company of Men
results.creator_credit: Fred Moore, Leon Clore and Basic Films
results.brief_description: Focuses attention on the more delicate question of the prejudices and resistance which may be encountered at all levels when Work Study is introduced into industry. The story is based on the day-to-day record of a six-months period in an engineering firm in the Midlands, and is presented as a realistic account of the difficulties experienced and overcome, in an effort to bring fundamental problems into open discussion.

results.title: A Communications primer
results.brief_description: This visually beautiful film was a first in a lot of ways: the Eameses’ first film scored by Elmer Bernstein, their first to deal with specific intellectual content, and the film that introduced their work to IBM. The elegant and clear statement remains essential viewing for the Media Age. The film deals with the ways in which human beings obtain their essential knowledge of the outside world. It has not always been recognised that communications consist of something more than the transmission of facts or symbols, and a mere facility for handling certain devices. What is required is an understanding of the human attributes and processes which control the passage of information from one person to another. The film will help discourage a limited view of communications. There are a number of philosophical implications, and some good illustrative samples on the concept of noise in a communication system, and provocative photographic symbolism about the power of words to add or detract to human knowledge. Music by Elmer Bernstein, sound by Barry Eddy.
